family_friendly.description: Important to know for Laugh Track City or Family Friendly Matinee

categories.name: Opening Games
categories.description: Warm-up and opening games to start a show

games.name: Categories

setup.description: Players stand in a line. Host gets a topic from the audience.

rules: Host points to each player who must name something in the category
Eliminations occur on hesitation, incorrect answers, or host decision
Host may give endowments instead of eliminating (accents, impressions, dance moves)
tips: Practice heightening - start obvious, get more obscure
Listen to fellow players for patterns
Embrace failure - fail big!
Commit to any endowments given

games.name: Home Shopping Network

setup.description: One or two people designated as guessers leave the room. Host collects five items with unique traits (e.g., "microwave POWERED BY tofu"). Clue givers write down items and decide who gives what clue.

rules: One side goes 1‚Üí2‚Üí3, other side goes 5‚Üí4‚Üí3
Guessers race to claim the middle item
Clue givers may ONLY use pantomime, no gibberish
If one guesser, go 1‚Üí5

tips: Be a character - you're a QVC host!
Keep upbeat attitude and energy
Tell a narrative, don't just list guesses
Eyes on clue givers at all times
Cheat out towards audience while ensuring guesser can see
Show the NEED for the product first
Definitively indicate when product is guessed (clap and point)
For non-electric power, pantomime unplugging from outlet

games.name: Mash Up

setup.description: Host creates whiteboard with 4 quadrants, each with a theme (characters, occupation, genre, obsession, location, etc.). Gather 16 total suggestions (4 per quadrant).

rules: Players stand in backline
One player steps up and mashes up two suggestions from different quadrants
Host asks to see the scene
Players do short scene of the mash up
Host walks in front and audience says "MASH UP!" to end scene
Continue until all suggestions are used

games.name: My Movie

setup.description: Players stand in a line with host in front. Get suggestion of a letter or film genre.

rules: Host conducts players to say "My Movie, My Movie, My Movie"
Host points at player who names a made-up movie title using suggestion
When audience/host likes a title (indicated by "oooo"), player gives tagline
If host likes it, they say "let's see it!" and players do short scene
Host calls scene by walking back to middle
Get new suggestion or continue with same

games.name: Playground Insults

setup.description: Host sends one player from each side out as guessers. Get suggestion of insult in form: Adjective ‚Üí Verb-ing ‚Üí Noun (each word 3+ syllables).

rules: Guessers take on personas of kids arguing and insulting each other
Kids face each other with backs to their team's clue givers
Teammates break down syllables and pantomime them
Guessers work guesses into their insults
Host switches between teams every 10-20 seconds
First guesser to call the full insult wins

tips: Character is typically a child on playground
Repeat what other guesser said when clue givers are running on stage
Break down syllables with team beforehand
Have backup pantomimes ready
Syllables don't have to be perfect pronunciations

examples: Air (breathing in air) | Row (rowing a boat) | mat (doormat) | Tic (tic on a dog)
Arrow (Shooting a bow and arrow)
The syllables do not have to be perfect pronunciations

games.name: Scattergories

setup.description: Similar to Categories. Players stand in a line, host gets topic from audience.

rules: Host points to each player who must name something in category
After any response, host can say "Which is also‚Ä¶"
Player must name new topic their response could belong to
Topic changes to this new topic
Eliminations on hesitation, incorrect answers, or host decision
tips: Practice heightening - start obvious, get more obscure
Listen to fellow players for patterns
Embrace failure - fail big!
examples: P1: Shark
P2: Beta Fish
P3: Gold Fish
Host: Which is also a‚Ä¶
P3: Type of Snack
P2: Potato Chips

games.name: Sideline Debate

setup.description: The guessers are called back in and take on the personas of politicians debating the pros and cons of Verb-ing ‚Üí Adjective ‚Üí Noun. The politicians face each other with each having their back to the other team‚Äôs clue givers.

rules: The host sends one player from each side out of the room to be the guessers and gets the suggestion of a Verb-ing ‚Üí Adjective ‚Üí Noun, each word having three or more syllables.
The host will determine which team will go first, and their teammates will get across the first word by breaking it down into smaller syllable chunks and getting them across through pantomime.
When the Verb-ing word is guessed, the teams will move on to the Adjective, and then the Noun.
The first guesser will try to guess what the syllable is working their guesses into their insults.
tips: The first guesser will try to guess what the syllable is working their guesses into their insults.

games.name: Sideline Karaoke

setup.description: The host sends one player from each side out of the room to be the guessers and gets five multi word songs titles from the audience.

tips: The guessers then run back into the room and each grab a microphone. A pianist or soundbooth will provide a backing track. Similar to Home Shopping Network, each guesser needs to guess two songs and race to get the middle song. Clue givers will be pantomiming entire words to the guessers, which will help the guesser build the whole song title together. The guessers are singing the entire time as they guess the song titles. The first team to guess three songs wins!

games.name: Simon

setup.description: The host will then get an activity or location. The first player then does a motion related to the suggestion and names it. The second player then does that first motion, then does a new motion and names it.

rules: Two players start onstage against each other, similar to What Are You Doing and Top That.
tips: Two players start onstage and an activity is suggested from the audience. One player will start by stepping up and doing a quick, repeatable motion, then going back to neutral and saying ‚Äútry that on for size‚Äù or ‚Äútop that.‚Äù The other player will then step up, do the same motion but justify it differently, and then end with ‚Äútry that on for size‚Äù or ‚Äútop that.‚Äù This goes back and forth until an elimination occurs, which comes if a player hesitates, repeats, or the host finds a reason to move the game along.
For later rounds, avoid doing a motion that was already done. If arms were used up in the air, do something with your legs or use a prop.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm dropping a baby‚Ä¶ try that on for size‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm catching that baby‚Ä¶ try that on for size‚Äù
I did a show where the thing was gymnastics and the person threw their arms in the air like a landing pose. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing gymnastics‚Ä¶ try that on for size‚Äù
My friend said ‚ÄúY‚Ä¶ try that on for size‚Äù (like YMCA by the Village People). Got a major pop!
examples: Player 1: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes
Player 2: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes ‚Üí I‚Äôm pumping the ball
Player 1: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes ‚Üí I‚Äôm pumping the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dribbling the ball
Player 2: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes ‚Üí I‚Äôm pumping the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dribbling the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dunking on you
Player 1: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes ‚Üí I‚Äôm pumping the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dribbling the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dunking on you ‚Üí I‚Äôm getting a technical by punching you
Player 2: I‚Äôm lacing up my shoes ‚Üí I‚Äôm pumping the ball ‚Üí I‚Äôm dunking on you
Host: That‚Äôs wrong!
Top That
Player 1: *Does a shooting a basketball motion* I‚Äôm playing Basketball‚Ä¶ Try that on for size
Player 2: *Does a shooting a basketball motion* I‚Äôm high-fiving a giant‚Ä¶ Try that on for size
Player 1: *Does a shooting a basketball motion* I‚Äôm putting things on the top shelf‚Ä¶ Try that on for size
Player 2: *Does a shooting a basketball motion* I‚Äôm Mufasa trying to grab Scar‚Äôs paw‚Ä¶ Try that on for size
Host: Aww‚Ä¶ too soon, you‚Äôre OUT!
Do a motion that is easily repeatable! If you do something like get on your knees, well you‚Äôre doing it to yourself! If it‚Äôs a motion you can‚Äôt do, do it your own way in safe manner.
The action and first justification should be related to the topic. If it‚Äôs volleyball, it‚Äôs as simple as ‚ÄúI‚Äôm playing volleyball,‚Äù I‚Äôm spiking the ball,‚Äù I‚Äôm setting the ball,‚Äù etc.
The later justifications can be nothing related to volleyball.
Feel free to build a story if it seems possible
Instead of just ‚ÄúI‚Äôm dancing,‚Äù you can say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm dancing to Chappell Roan‚Äù
Usually we want to say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm‚Ä¶‚Äù at the start of everything, but feel free to switch it up sometimes.

games.name: Top That (Try That on For Size)

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of top that (try that on for size).

games.name: Video Dating Service

setup.description: The guessers are called back in and take on the personas of people looking for love. The guessers face each other with each having their back to the other team‚Äôs clue givers. The first guesser will try to guess what the syllable is while maintaining the character.

rules: The host sends one player from each side out of the room to be the guessers and gets the suggestion of the types of people the guessers are looking for in the form of Adjective ‚Üí Occupation ‚Üí Hobby, each word having three or more syllables.
The host will determine which team will go first, and their teammates will get across the first word by breaking it down into smaller syllable chunks and getting them across through pantomime.
When the adjective word is guessed, the teams will move on to the occupation, and then the hobby.
tips: The first guesser will try to guess what the syllable is while maintaining the character.

games.name: What You Got

setup.description: A group of 6-8 are onstage in two teams. A suggestion is received from the audience in the form of a broad topic, activity, event, etc. One person from each team is front and center with the other posse members behind that person.

tips: Make sure to attach a specific action to the commands. Even if the command is not action-based, like ‚ÄúI‚Äôm waiting for the bus‚Äù, make it a big action!
Don‚Äôt try to cram big sentences into your actions. Be simple. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm da da da da‚Äù ‚Äîthat‚Äôs it
examples: Leader 1: I‚Äôm Throwing the Bouquet Leader 1 & Posse: Throwing the Bouquet, Throwing the Bouquet, What You Got!
Leader 2: I‚Äôm Giving a Toast Leader 2 & Posse: Giving a Toast, Giving a Toast, What You Got
The teams go back and forth until there‚Äôs hesitation, a fall off the beat, or too much repetition.
Be safe! If you can‚Äôt do the action without hurting yourself, don‚Äôt. However, make up for it with your voice and attitude.
If you‚Äôre the leader, be clear and loud. Reach your posse members.
Heighten the commands. Start with typical actions and build up to more absurd or extreme actions.

If you‚Äôre a leader and your opposing leader does a command that elicits a big reaction, feel free to end the round by bowing out of the competition or intentionally losing. It‚Äôs like an edit in a Montage. Let‚Äôs reset with a new round.

games.name: What Are You Doing

setup.description: Two players onstage. Suggestions start with actions (sport, chore, hobby), then transition to letters.

rules: One player does random action or dancing
Other player yells "What Are You Doing!"
First player stops, goes to neutral, says something they're NOT doing
Second player does what they were endowed with
Continue until elimination (hesitation, repetition, saying what you're actually doing)
tips: Do big actions and VOCALIZE
Think of these as solo miniature scenes
Avoid narrating/repeating the prompt
Justify absurd actions with big characters
Give and accept the absurd - COMMIT!
Stop action when partner says "What are you doing!" and make eye contact
Try to eliminate "I'm" - use letter sound instead (B-b-b-baking a cake)
"What Are You Doing" is a statement, not a question
Allow partner to finish thought before interrupting
examples: Player 1: Starts Randomly Moving
Player 2: What Are You Doing!
Player 1: Dribbling Basketballs
Player 2: Starts dribbling basketballs
Player 1: What Are You Doing!
Player 2: Shooting Threes
Player 1: Starts Shooting Threes
Player 2: What Are You Doing!
Player 1: Traveling
Player 2: 1 airline ticket to Belize, please
Do big actions and VOCALIZE! Make the game equally as fun for a hard-of-hearing audience member and a visually-impaired audience member.

Try to eliminate ‚ÄúI‚Äôm,‚Äù since it just becomes a delay tactic at that point. Instead, use the sound of the letter to inspire you about an example (eg: B-b-b-baking a cake). The audience thinks that giving us a letter makes the game more difficult, but it is actually a gift we can use to create fun activities.
"What Are You Doing" is a statement (or exclamation) not a question.
Allow your partner to finish their thought before saying "What Are You Doing!" The game should be fast, but thoughts/ideas should be finished.
Don‚Äôt get frustrated; get excited! Short form is designed to make you fail. To be comfortable with failure shows success in short form.

categories.name: Audience Games
categories.description: Games that involve audience members directly

games.name: 4 Square

setup.description: 4 performers in square formation. Front 2 receive suggestion, then rotate.

rules: Front 2 performers receive suggestion
Host shouts "rotate right" and square shifts
New pair front and center receives suggestion
Continue until all 4 pairs have suggestions (you're in 2 pairs)
Front pair jumps into scene when game begins
Host shouts "rotate right (or left)" to end scene and rotate
tips: When you return to scene, time has passed - heighten to new moment
Think cause and effect
Have strong relationship
Listen to host - they may rotate different direction or multiple times

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of audience recap (telephone).

games.name: Audience SFx

setup.description: Audience member given microphone to provide sound effects. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Audience member provides sound effects based on scene actions
Players must justify all sound effects given
tips: Use exposition to help audience member know what you're doing
Verbally announce actions: "Hold on, let me get the axe"
JUSTIFY all sound effects - react appropriately
Allow pauses for sound effects
Play tennis - take turns prompting (50/50)

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of bedtime/campfire story.

games.name: Casanova

setup.description: Two teams of 3 (or 4) compete to win the favor of an audience member. Based on a suggestion, the teams try to come up with the best pick up line, but they must speak one word at a time. Teams conclude their pick up line by saying "YEAAAAAHHHHH!" together.

rules: When you receive the suggestion, freely associate words in your head and see if you can drop them into your team's pick up line.
tips: Based on a suggestion, the teams try to come up with the best pick up line, but they must speak one word at a time.
So if the suggestion was rabbit, rather than actually saying the suggestion in the pick up line, try to drop in an association word.

"Hey baby, I think you should hop into my heart." "What‚Äôs up doc, you could never bug me." Similar to what you do in the stand-in-the-line pun games like ‚ÄúI Kissed A‚Ä¶‚Äù Since you're speaking one word at a time, the biggest focus is on speaking quickly and coherently.
So use proper grammar.
Be confident!
Especially with the "YEEAAAAAHHHHH!" If a mistake happens, don't call it out, just finish the line confidently.

A few types of responses are to try a short pick up line (they can be 2-3 words and that‚Äôs all you need), start with a Question then Answer it, change tone (usually sexy is what we default to, but maybe trying loving or enthusiastic

games.name: Center of Attention/Pretty Pretty Princess

setup.description: This game is similar to 4 Square, except the audience volunteer is in every scene and every scene is a three-person scene. 4 Performers are onstage in a square formation with the audience member in the middle. The front 2 performers receive a suggestion.

rules: When the game begins, the pair front and center jump into a scene.
When the host shouts ‚Äúrotate right (or left)‚Äù the scene ends and the square rotates appropriately.

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of coffee break.
A game where players perform based on the concept of columns.
A game where players perform based on the concept of day in the life.
A game where players perform based on the concept of dinner at joe‚Äôs.
A game where players perform based on the concept of dubbing.

games.name: Moving Bodies

setup.description: Players cannot move on their own. Audience member moves them like action figures.

rules: Players cannot move themselves
Audience member physically moves players
Players must verbally indicate desired movements
Adjust and justify if audience member moves you unexpectedly
tips: Verbally indicate movements: "I'm walking over there to pick up that basket"
Repeat if volunteer doesn't respond
Justify overzealous movements

setup.description: Peter Pan‚Äôs Shadow (Virtual Reality)
A game where players perform based on the concept of peter pan‚Äôs shadow (virtual reality).

games.name: Slo-Mo Olympics

setup.description: Olympic event of mundane/non-sport activity. Get suggestion.

rules: Athletes warm up at regular speed while being introduced
Starting pistol fires (or commentators start match)
Athletes switch to slow motion
Commentators describe as high-stakes sporting event
Game ends when athlete crosses finish line or vanquishes opponent

tips: Start strong - welcome audience, introduce yourself, event, then athletes
React to what athletes are pantomiming
Play with athletes - instant replays, zoom in
Lead athletes to actions
Don't talk over fellow commentator
Maintain excitement, avoid dead air
Before match, hint at character - good guy (face) or bad guy (heel)
Play with props related to competition
Go slow when match starts, match competitor's speed
Make pantomiming distinct, especially hands
React big with movements and facial expressions
Earnestly do activity first, then sabotage opponent
Use things related to activity when sabotaging
Do 4-5 fighting beats during slo-mo
Generally bad guy should lose

notes: This can be played with an audience member as an athlete. As the fellow athlete, take care of the audience member and let them win.

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of subtext.

games.name: What If?

setup.description: The host interviews an audience volunteer about a recent major life decision, then players perform scenes showing what would have happened if they'd made a different choice.

rules: The host first interviews a volunteer about a recent major life or positive decision they made, then ask follow up questions like who they were with when they were making the decision (family, friend, partner, etc.), whom the decision affected, and any other natural questions that come up.
One player must play the volunteer (either the volunteer chooses or players choose) and the other players will play supporting roles.
Scene 1: Establish the decision and choose the alternate path
Scene 2: Show the initial fallout revealing it was a bad choice
Scene 3+: Heighten the consequences, making things progressively worse
End by asking the volunteer: "Aren't you glad you made that decision?"
tips: Keep the interview quick and focused on gathering key details about the decision

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of word from our sponsor.
A game where players perform based on the concept of word up from our sponsor.

categories.description: Games where the host can interrupt and modify the scene

games.name: 4 Square

setup.description: 4 performers in square formation. Front 2 receive suggestion, then rotate.

rules: Front 2 performers receive suggestion
Host shouts "rotate right" and square shifts
New pair front and center receives suggestion
Continue until all 4 pairs have suggestions (you're in 2 pairs)
Front pair jumps into scene when game begins
Host shouts "rotate right (or left)" to end scene and rotate
tips: When you return to scene, time has passed - heighten to new moment
Think cause and effect
Have strong relationship
Listen to host - they may rotate different direction or multiple times

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of actor switch.
A game where players perform based on the concept of big little.
A game where players perform based on the concept of calvin ball.
A game where players perform based on the concept of changing emotions & stuff.

games.name: Conjunction Junction

setup.description: Players begin neutral scene. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Host interrupts and calls out conjunction (and, or, but, because, also, etc.)
Last player who spoke repeats conjunction and expands sentence
Host may call multiple conjunctions in a row

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of continuation.
A game where players perform based on the concept of d&d in the life.
A game where players perform based on the concept of death pendulum.
A game where players perform based on the concept of dick van dyke.
A game where players perform based on the concept of dvd.

games.name: Forward Reverse

setup.description: Scene game where host can shout 'reverse' to make scene go backwards. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Host shouts 'reverse' and scene progresses backwards
Host says 'forward' to resume forward motion
Scene may go in reverse beyond first sentence
tips: Driven by action and characters
Combine dialogue with specific movement/action
Use whole stage, move around
Keep dialogue concise for easier memory
Think in reverse - set up the activity you started with
Don't worry about mistakes, embrace them
Keep momentum going

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of genre switch.
A game where players perform based on the concept of gibberish switch.
A game where players perform based on the concept of growing shrinking machine.

games.name: Hey Morty

setup.description: Scene game best played dramatically. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Players perform dramatic scene
Host interrupts by calling player's name and repeating a word (usually noun)
Player tells pun based on word in over-the-top manner

Format:
   - Player: "Hey, Morty!"
   - All: "Yeah, Morty?!"
   - Player: "Did you hear the one about X?"
   - All: "No, Morty. We didn't hear the one about X."
   - Player: [Pun]
   - ALL: "HA!" [with jazz hands]
Scene continues as if pun never happened
tips: Pun doesn't have to be good - fun, stupid vibe
Players not in scene can jump on stage for call and response

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of identity crisis.
A game where players perform based on the concept of inner monologue.
A game where players perform based on the concept of monkey in the middle.

games.name: New Choice

setup.description: Host can call NEW CHOICE and player must say something different. Get scene suggestion.

rules: Host calls NEW CHOICE on player
Player must say something different from what was said
Host may NEW CHOICE actions, reactions, or anything
tips: Keep sentences short with pauses
Make actual change, don't just repeat differently
Change beginning of sentences, not just last word
Think Rule of Threes: Regular > Weird > Crazy Town
Character motivations can remain intact
Prompt host with nice gifts to NEW CHOICE
examples: "Surprise, I got you a new car!" *NEW CHOICE*
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs a half-eaten Snickers bar.‚Äù *NEW CHOICE*
"I married your daughter, we cool?"
Mainly say a new choice; get away from the first choice in some way
AVOID:
‚ÄúYou look beautiful.‚Äù *NEW CHOICE*
‚ÄúYou look awful.‚Äù *NEW CHOICE*
‚ÄúYou look suspicious.‚Äù *NEW CHOICE*
‚ÄúYou look meh.‚Äù
Think Rule of Three‚Äôs with your new choice: Regular > Weird > Crazy Town
Your character‚Äôs motivations can remain intact, even if the new choices adds twists and turns
The host is also a player in this game too and it‚Äôs fun when the host is clearly messing with the players on stage.

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of oscar winning moment.
A game where players perform based on the concept of parallel universe.
A game where players perform based on the concept of rhyme it.
A game where players perform based on the concept of say that differently.

games.name: Scantron

setup.description: Cast members do a scene and at any point in time, the host can shout "FREEZE". The scene is generally heightened by the amount of players.

tips: Cast members stand still and the host will prompt each player to make a choice on "What happens next..." Once every player says their thing, the host will have each player repeat it so the audience can vote on which choice they want to see based on their applause.

Sell your choice with your voice and body language Typically Option A (the 1st choice) will be a more logical choice Options B - D can be more extreme and heightened Try to make your choices relevant to the story It‚Äôs okay if they go off the rails because you said the first thing that came to mind, I would rather have you say something than spend time thinking in silence Using ‚ÄúWE‚Äù instead of ‚ÄúI‚Äù invites everyone be involved in the scene Once the audience has voted for the choice they want to see, immediately start transitioning to that choice and justifying it

games.name: Shakespeare Switch

setup.description: The players start out doing a neutral scene based on the suggestion. Moments that happened in the scene may carry over throughout the switches, but the fun of it is justifying differently. In the Shakespearean mode, you challenge someone to a duel.

rules: Whenever the host wishes, they yell out ‚ÄúSwitch‚Äù and the players must immediately switch from their normal scene to a Shakespearean inspired play.
The host will then yell ‚ÄúSwitch‚Äù again and the players will return to the neutral scene.
The host may call ‚ÄúSwitch‚Äù whenever they like throughout the scene until the game ends.
tips: Do NOT overuse -TH at the end of every word.
Thou is commonly used, so that‚Äôs fine.
Keep in mind themes found in Shakespear plays, just like when you play Genre Replay.
Just because Shakespear sounds fancy, keep in mind that he was also a raunchy writer too.
Bonus points if you can make your Shakespearean dialogue rhyme!

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of spin off.

categories.name: Justification Games
categories.description: Games requiring quick thinking and justification

games.name: 90-Sec Alphabet

setup.description: Scene where each line starts with next letter of alphabet. Get scenario and starting letter.

rules: First word of first sentence begins with given letter
Next line begins with next letter, continuing through alphabet
Goal: get back to starting letter within 90 seconds
tips: Tell beginning, middle, and end within 90 seconds
Start in the middle of action
Use emotions and be a character
Do activities with your lines
You WILL make mistakes - get back on the bike
Don't panic or show WTF expression
Jump out of plane, figure it out on way down
Start with syllable of letter if you blank
examples: Performer A: Frank, looks like we‚Äôre going to have to close down. Nobody wants to eat at Denny‚Äôs anymore.
Performer B: Gosh darn it. What will the 3am boozehounds do without us?
Performer A: I don‚Äôt know (WHOOPS, skipped H)
Performer B: (going with the partner) James! We should fundraise
right now and see if we can make 2k by the end of the day.

A big saying in improv is "Jump out of the plane and figure out what to do on the way down." This rule REALLY applies in this game. Sometimes you get to a letter, and you blank on the "right" word to say. Just say something! Feel free to start with a syllable that begins with that letter and see where it leads. That's the fun of the game, right? The audience is in on this joke that you have these rules to follow.
Performer A: Ulysses, I'm afraid I'm going to have to let you go. Starbucks is making budget cuts.
Performer B: Vooooooocation school! I should have done vocation school! Now I don't have any skills.

setup.description: Ask for a scene suggestion and a letter of the alphabet. The letter becomes the first letter of the first line dialogue. Lines of dialogue alternate between actors, each beginning with the next letter of the alphabet, continuing until the host calls the game.

games.name: Acromania

setup.description: Perform a regular scene based on any suggestion. During the scene, an improviser may throw out an acronym of two or more letters. Another improviser must immediately give the full name the letters represent.

tips: GRAMMAR NOTE: No, these aren‚Äôt really acronyms because acronyms are pronounced as words (ex: LASER, SCUBA, FOMO).
examples: Person 1: I‚Äôll handle the dinner for tonight. All I need to do is call PTD.
Person 2: Preserve This Dinner? Great idea! They saved many events for me!
Don‚Äôt worry about what the letters could mean, that's up to the other improviser.
Don‚Äôt get caught in a letter rut, like starting or ending with all the same letters.
Get out an acronym earlier in the scene to show how the game works.
Add more letters later in the scene. As a gimmick, end with a long acronym.
notes: GRAMMAR NOTE: No, these aren't really acronyms because acronyms are pronounced as words (ex: LASER, SCUBA, FOMO). The abbreviation of a phrase pronounced by saying each letter is called an "initialism." I guess it was too obscure to call this game "Initialismania."

games.name: Angry Gods

setup.description: Two improvisers portray gods who stand on the sides of the stage and at least 2 others are ‚Äúmortals‚Äù performing a scene. The two mortals begin a scene. At any point, either god may clap to freeze the scene and insert a plague, problem, or solution based on their power.

games.name: Echoes

setup.description: For four improvisers performing three scenes with three separate suggestions. In the first scene, Actor 1 performs a short scene with Actor 2. In the second scene, Actor 2 performs a scene with Actor 3, but repeats all the lines they had in the scene with Actor 1.

tips: To increase the chances of remembering the dialogue, keep the scenes short and the dialogue distinct.
Actors 2 and 3 should avoid overly scene-specific dialogue, like names, that won't carry through as well.

setup.description: The host assigns each player a trigger word. When a player's word is spoken during the scene, they must immediately enter or exit the stage and justify their action.

rules: The host assigns each player a word that might come up in a casual conversation, gets a suggestion, and the players begin a neutral scene.

If their word is spoken while on stage, they must immediately exit and justify their exit.

games.name: Say Stuff, Do Things

setup.description: Players exit while the host collects dialogue lines and actions from the audience on slips of paper. Players return and perform a scene, picking up and incorporating the prompts as they go.

Have can be objects/props/costume, but it can also be your unique powers.
Say can include wordplay, puns. It can include catchphrases, too (Spiderman says "my Spidey senses are tingling"

When performer one is onstage. Become the character during "calm times". The situation hasn't happened yet. Drop a line, use physicality...what is this hero doing when nothing bad is happening, what is their routine? Then SHOW the urgent situation happening! Greg Proops always drops in a silly Superhero exclamation line: "Great Casear's Ghost!" "Holy Macaroni & Cheese!" or it can be something related to your character...it's almost like your catchphrase. Then reference the urgent situation, and then the next hero will join.

When each hero enters, quickly endow them. "Thank goodness you're here ________". Before we move on, we want to see how this hero affects the group dynamic. How does this hero change and affect the other hero(es).

categories.name: Guessing Games
categories.description: Games where performers must guess information

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of 5 things.

games.name: 5-Sided Die

setup.description: One player leaves while the host gathers 5 suggestions from the audience. Clue givers then pantomime each suggestion in sequence for the returning guesser.

rules: Each time it seems as if the guesser has understood the suggestion, the next clue giver enters and, with those already on stage, communicates the next suggestion.
When the guesser believes they understand the final suggestion, the host will pause the game to call the guesser forward.
tips: A guessing game that uses pantomime and gibberish, one guesser, and five clue-givers.
This keeps going until all five clue givers are working together.
When the guesser believes they understand the final suggestion, the host will pause the game to call the guesser forward.
This keeps going until the guesser gets down to the first suggestion.
examples: Suggested audience gets: Famous person or character, Common pairing (knife and fork, salt and vinegar, Abbott and Costello), Well-known story (Three Little Pigs, Garden of Eden, It's a Wonderful Life), Recognizable location (Statue of Liberty, France, Pyramids of Giza), Historical event

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of 6 things.

games.name: Blitzkrieg

setup.description: Using only pantomime and gibberish, the clue givers will put the guesser into the story, in the order that was suggested by the audience.

rules: The host sends one player out of the room to be the guesser and gets a list of 10 or more stories, video games, movies, television shows, etc.
The host then calls the guesser back in, and sets a certain amount of time (can range from 3 minutes to 5 minutes).
tips: The clue givers must try their best to make the guesser the main character of each suggestion.
Once the guesser thinks they know it, they will step forward and guess.

setup.description: Similar to Celebrity Uber, players take on celebrity characters while riding in a taxi. The driver must guess who the celebrities are.
A game where players perform based on the concept of celebrity uber (taxi).

games.name: Chain Murder

setup.description: This guessing game requires 4 players, and can be done with an audience member as the fourth person. 1 player stays while the rest of the team leaves the room. The goal is to give all clues, 1 player to the next (like a game of telephone), within 3 minutes.

rules: The host will get the following suggestions from the audience: a location, an occupation not related to the location, and a murder weapon that normally wouldn‚Äôt be used as a weapon (LOW).
The host will then ask all players to rise from the dead and starting with the fourth player, ask them what they thought the location, occupation and murder weapon was.
If the fourth player is wrong on one of them, they will go to the next player to see if they know what it is.
If someone did the golden arches and did the ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Loving It‚Äù jingle for McDonald‚Äôs, then find something else that you could give a clue for McDonald‚Äôs.
If you thought the location was Burger King, but the previous player said it and it was wrong, say something else, even if you 100% thought it was Burger King.
tips: The host will get the following suggestions from the audience: a location, an occupation not related to the location, and a murder weapon that normally wouldn‚Äôt be used as a weapon (LOW).
The first player will then use pantomime and gibberish to convey all three clues.

Once the second player believes they know the murder weapon, they will use it to murder the first player, and the audience shouts ‚Äúthey‚Äôre dead!‚Äù Then the next player runs in, and the second player will convey their clues to the next person and will ultimately be killed by the third player.
Avoid parroting what the previous person gave you as a clue.
I would rather you have fun!
It can be even funnier when you get it wrong because the audience is in on the joke and can see the trainwreck from the beginning, especially in a game of telephone!
examples: Crime: They watched a movie
Motive: Because they were hungry for spaghetti
Accomplice: They did it with Robert DeNiro.

The game is played like a scene in an interrogation room, where the criminal (guesser) has to guess the entire crime. Clue givers must drop subtle hints to get the guesser to correctly say the crime. Hints come in the form of puns, setting the scene, and describing the scenario. Clue givers cannot say any of the words in the crime: so you can't say "watched" or "movie," you must lead the guesser up to say it first. If the guesser does say a word that is part of the clue, then you may use it. The game is over once the guesser gets all three clues, or the host calls time.
Clue givers:
Start out subtle (puns are usually the most subtle), build up to more obvious clues.
Pick a strong character (good cop, bad cop generally start, if there are three clue givers, someone can come in as a lawyer, another cop, a lover, a fellow criminal, etc).
A third person can enter and leave as an additional clue giver, sometime during the second clue or the first clue if the guesser is struggling.

Giving clues is like climbing a ladder. Get the guesser to say each word one at a time: get him/her to say hungry, then get him/her to say spaghetti. Positive reinforcement! If they say HUNGRY! Say "YES, you were hungry..but what did you want is the question!" Saying yes tells the guesser if they are on the right track.
Guesser:
Pick a strong character! It's a guessing game, but still play the scene.
By constantly throwing out guesses (I call ‚Äúactive guessing‚Äù), you are subtly informing your clue givers where your train of thought is and then they can pivot with their clues.
Gauge the time. If you know the answer right off the bat, play a little "dumb". The audience loves the struggle.

I was in a game where we had 30 seconds left and they said ‚ÄúShake it Off.‚Äù I immediately knew it was Taylor Swift as my accomplice, but I played dumb to build up the tension and eventually end the game strong at nearly the last possible moment.
When you‚Äôre ready to guess the last clue (the accomplice), say the whole thing: crime, motivation and accomplice.

A game where players perform based on the concept of csi: crime scene improvisor.

games.name: Dating Game

setup.description: This is a guessing game with one guesser and three clue givers. While the guesser is outside, the guessers each get a suggestion for a character. These can be anything from objects, high school cliques, occupations, celebrities, fictional characters, historical figures, etc.

rules: The host will help facilitate and give additional clues if needed, or make quips!
If you know pop culture well, pick a celebrity, musician, etc.
If you aren't too versed in actual people, be an object or occupation.
If they can easily guess who you are by the first round, then you're being too obvious.
If the question is, "Where would you take me on our first date?" avoid giving a one-word answer.
If you are a spatula, then what type of spatula are you?
When guessing, start with someone you're pretty confident you know the answer to, then the one you're not so sure about, then end with one you are 100% confident in (or the most confident in).
When you guess, preface it by naming the bachelor number you are guessing for.
tips: Once the 3 rounds conclude, the guesser guesses the two he/she did not choose, and the person he/she did choose!
The host will help facilitate and give additional clues if needed, or make quips!
If the question is, "Where would you take me on our first date?" avoid giving a one-word answer.
Give your character a personality!
Commit hard to your character, even if you don't know a lot about it.
Embody the character even when the spotlight isn‚Äôt on you, avoid going to a neutral stance when you‚Äôre not talking.
Guesser Feel free to be a character yourself!
This makes it so the game ends on a pop!
"You know...I don't think I can choose bachelor #2, because I'm allergic to fish...Aquaman!
Be confident with your guesses!
Some of the most fun in short form is being wrong, because it gives us a chance to see how your mind connects different dots to get to a completely new idea!

tips: One set of improvisers returns, is given the genre, and creates a scene, trying to incorporate as many clich√©s as they can think of.
Someone not in the scene ticks the list of audience-provided clich√©s as they‚Äôre used, the audience is encouraged to clap any time they spot a suggested clich√©.

setup.description: A game where players perform based on the concept of guess that thing!.
A game where players perform based on the concept of hot bell.

One guesser is sent out of the room while one player is designated the boss and two others as the coworkers. The guesser will guess what activity made them late, why they did it and who is their alibi.

tips: The premise of this game is that you‚Äôre late for work and you‚Äôre making up your excuse on the spot with the help of your coworkers. Once you realize you‚Äôre in trouble, start looking at your coworkers behind your boss and look to them for help.
Project and have fun with the struggle, you and the boss are going to be auditorily filling the space as the game goes on.

The fun of this game is always the journey with guessing. If you‚Äôre unsure with your guess and you know it‚Äôs wrong, still say it with confidence. The audience knows the answer, so they get enjoyment when they can be like, ‚ÄúHaha, no you‚Äôre wrong!‚Äù
Listen to the time cues shouted out by the host, you generally want to give 1 minute per guess.
If the guesser is still not getting it after time is winding down, don‚Äôt be afraid to be really obvious with the clues.
Boss
Give subtle verbal clues at first, as the fun of it is mainly from the pantomime given by the coworkers
Once per section, the boss should look back and catch the coworkers in place with their pantomime. You‚Äôre providing a gift for the coworkers to justify whatever silly position they are in.
You‚Äôre leading the conversation to make sure the guesser is on the right track with their guesses. If they‚Äôre venturing too far off, correct them.
Have fun with the jerk boss character, you‚Äôre the comedic foil!
Coworkers
Start pantomiming once you see the guesser look towards you like they‚Äôre ready to start fibbing their way into an excuse.
Similar to HSN, Playground Insults and 5 or 6 Things, establish the scene to provide better context for your clue.
When the boss turns around, freeze or continue doing your motion (do NOT revert to a normal stance). It‚Äôs fun to see what justification you give to whatever you‚Äôre doing.
Find moments when you can make a big noise to get the boss‚Äôs attention to turn around. If you find yourselves in a silly moment, prompting them can yield fun results!
Stage Picture: make sure you‚Äôre both seen by the audience and by the guesser.

games.name: Party Quirks

setup.description: One performer is the Host of a party (the Guesser). The other three performers secretly receive a prompt for a character (usually something kind of bizarre). A doorbell will ring and the Guest 1 will come in.

rules: The host begins the game by doing a quick line to set up the fact that they are having a party.
When you first enter the party, the full focus is on YOU.
tips: Through clues, the Host will try to guess who each performer is.
Party Guests I won't get into too many tips for playing the characters, because I've already talked about that in games like Let's Make a Date & Weird Newscasters.
Main thing is to COMMIT and not just limit yourself to verbal clues (be physical).
When you first enter the party, the full focus is on YOU.
Use this time to truly become the character.
Once the doorbell rings, you will have light focus.
You can still do subtle physical activities, because the Guesser will still be looking at you at times.
In short, don't go neutral, you're still in the game.
Don't just let the conversation be between the Host and Party Guest #3.
Take, take, take!
Although the number 1 priority is to truly commit to the character, a side priority is to aim your clues around reality (being at a party).
So, if you're playing the "The Titanic sinking", instead of just screaming "ICEBERG!!!!"....maybe scream "ICEBERG salad!
My favorite, I am on a diet you know?" Try to keep your clues within the context of the attending a party, so the game doesn't become disconnected.
Also keep doing it, up until you hear the doorbell.
You are keeping this party together.

A lot of the comedy comes from a bizarre character entering and after they provide their bizarre clues, you say something grounded around the party, "Can I get you some artichoke dip?" So just like the guests, you also need to stay in character!
Try to avoid guessing right away.
Also, try to not be confused by these weird people at this party.

games.name: Press Conference

setup.description: One performer is holding a press conference as a CHARACTER who is announcing SOMETHING. They do not know who they are and what they are announcing. The other 3 performers are reporters who ask questions trying to clue the presenter into their endowments.

rules: If your character is Santa Claus, then you might drop a reference to elves.
When you do that, then the reporters should pivot to giving clues towards the announcement.
When you are called on for the 1st time, I recommend naming yourself and who you represent
tips: The other 3 performers are reporters who ask questions trying to clue the presenter into their endowments.
It's as though the previous line was the announcement that the guesser is trying to guess.
Don't worry about guessing.
examples: It doesn't have to be a joke or a clue. It just helps contribute to the reality. ‚ó¶ Similar to News Flash, the first few questions can be simple and open ended. After that you can give subtle clues, puns, play-on-words, etc.
You can also play with being actual reporters
A few examples:
Scribble frantically when something big is given
Give a vocal response to something gossipy
Take a quick picture.

tips: Paul Revere - Instrumental (If you want to practice on your own)
The game will keep going until a player hesitates, falls off the meter or repeats a word that has been said previously.

If you can‚Äôt think of any words that rhyme, then that means you can use any word* (Please keep it appropriate) you want! Fail big, go out on top by using a word that absolutely doesn‚Äôt rhyme at all like banana! The audience is expecting a rhyme so it can be funny to subvert those expectations with a line that keeps to the story but doesn‚Äôt rhyme.

Super secret extra credit points are given if you can keep a consistent narrative going throughout the song. This can be extremely challenging, but it can provide fun opportunities for you to throw yourself out in ways that keep with the story but don‚Äôt rhyme.
examples: Performer A: I know this dude and his name is...
Posse A: GREG!
Performer B: He stands real strong on only one...
Posse B: LEG!
Performer A: He‚Äôs a pro at cracking an...
Posse A: EGG!
Performer B: You want some breakfast, you‚Äôll have to...
Posse B: BEG!
Anytime there‚Äôs a mistake, new performers rotate in. Mistakes come in the form of
hesitating, falling off the beat, or repeating a word that‚Äôs been said.
This game is based off the rap group Beastie Boys, and here are some of their songs:

setup.description: The host will start by getting two initials from the audience.

rules: The host will start by getting two initials from the audience.
The host will then stall time for about 30 seconds while the players think of an entirely new game, both the name and how it‚Äôs played.

The host will clear the stage and players one at a time will present the name of the game and succinctly describe how it‚Äôs played to the audience (just one or two sentences, you can give more details if your game gets chosen).
tips: If you can‚Äôt think of an entirely new game and premise, just reskin an existing game. ‚ÄúHey Girl‚Äù is basically ‚ÄúI Kissed A‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚ÄúI like my lover‚Ä¶‚Äù

examples: Game: Epic Rap

Description: Players will be doing a scene and then the host can yell ‚ÄúEpic Rap,‚Äù then music will play and the players will start rapping. The host will then yell, ‚ÄúWord!‚Äù and they will then stop rapping and go back to the scene.
Game: Hey Girl (or Guy)

SELL!
SELL!
SELL!

rules: Players stand on stage, forming a half circle around the host.
The host gets an object from the audience that you wouldn‚Äôt really need a manual to use the product.
The host will point at a player and they must begin talking.

Player 1: This pencil is special because it does not write with lead, it‚Äì (host stops pointing) Player 2: (host points now at them) ‚Äìwrites with blood from Zues, the Greek‚Äì (host stops pointing) Player 3: (host points now at them) ‚ÄìGod of Thunder.

tips: The host gets an object from the audience that you wouldn‚Äôt really need a manual to use the product.

Once received, the host will start pointing at the players to provide the introductory chapter of this product, which is a nice time to showcase that this product is no ordinary version of it, but it‚Äôs special!

Player 1: This pencil is special because it does not write with lead, it‚Äì (host stops pointing) Player 2: (host points now at them) ‚Äìwrites with blood from Zues, the Greek‚Äì (host stops pointing) Player 3: (host points now at them) ‚ÄìGod of Thunder.
OR Player 1: To properly lubricate this pencil, please use wa‚Äì Player 2: ‚Äìtermelons.
You are the expert on this product!
If you say things that don‚Äôt make sense in the real world, that‚Äôs okay because this is a unique product that you and your fellow players only know!
Remember the details previously said, even if they were from earlier rounds.
Callbacks are always fun!
LISTEN!
Also, focus your attention on the host because they may be pointing to you soon.
Look with your eyes, listen with your ears.
Not all hosts do this, but typically we try to signal that we‚Äôre pointing to you next by making intense eye contact.
Don‚Äôt worry about messing up!

ALL PLAYERS: CASTLE Player 1: A Player 2: Castle Player 3: Is Player 1: Where Player 2: The Player 3: Prince Player 1: Lives ALL PLAYERS: CASTLE Play at the top of your intelligence, the fun of this game is genuine and honest mistakes rather than contrived and forced mistakes Do your best with keeping up the speed of the game.

games.name: Slo-Mo Olympics

setup.description: Olympic event of mundane/non-sport activity. Get suggestion.

Commentators describe as high-stakes sporting event

tips: Start strong - welcome audience, introduce yourself, event, then athletes
React to what athletes are pantomiming
Play with athletes - instant replays, zoom in
Lead athletes to actions
Don't talk over fellow commentator
Maintain excitement, avoid dead air
Before match, hint at character - good guy (face) or bad guy (heel)
Play with props related to competition
Go slow when match starts, match competitor's speed
Make pantomiming distinct, especially hands
React big with movements and facial expressions
Earnestly do activity first, then sabotage opponent
Use things related to activity when sabotaging

Generally bad guy should lose

games.name: Story

Next person picks up EXACTLY where previous left off (mid-sentence/word)
Elimination game - mess ups result in leaving stage
New chapters announced after eliminations
tips: Actions more important than dialogue/description
Avoid delay tactics like "decided to"
Use action words to keep plot going
LISTEN - don't think of your own story

Keep story simple, follow first idea and heighten
Don't solve problems, keep struggle going

Fall on grenade if no one has failed in a while

games.name: Switch Interview

setup.description: Fast-paced game where 2 people are on stage as a guest and host of a late night talk show, while the rest of the cast is on the back wall. A suggestion is given and they do a quick riff before the switch is called.

tips: Commit to it strongly because the scene will last no more than 10 seconds.
It might be called on a really good initiation line Try to incorporate an action into the segment, it can help justify the suggestion rather than just talking about it.
Remember the roles of Host & Guest; stick to the format of a talk show but you have freedom to be creative.

So if the segment starts with the guest steering the ship to a boat; the Host might respond: "Ladies & Gentlemen, we are about to experience a pillage by none other than Black Beard himself and might I say what a full & black beard it is!" This game benefits from variety, change it up!

setup.description: A title is received from the audience, and two groups of performers are onstage. One group tells the story, and one person from the other group acts it out (no dialogue or sound effects). The narrative group forms a line and the first person in line starts the story (3rd person perspective).

rules: When the Host shouts "SWITCH", the groups switch roles.
If you look at them, then your story becomes less progressive because you‚Äôre letting them decide your story.
tips: That person keeps telling the story until the person behind them taps them on the back and continues EXACTLY where they left off.
If you look at them, then your story becomes less progressive because you‚Äôre letting them decide your story.
Build the game up to controlled chaos!
For most of the story, use action!
Avoid the phrase "decided to..." it's a delay tactic and doesn't actually progress the story.
Big actions and justification!
BE EVERYTHING!

games.name: Weird Newscasters

setup.description: 4 Performers Needed. Performer A is the main anchor who receives no character endowment. Performer B is the co-anchor, who receives an endowment.

rules: If you start strong, then judge yourself, and back off your character, you're too in your head.
If you feel like it's right to move onto the next part of the game, then take focus and redirect it there.
tips: The Main Anchor introduces the show and themselves (usually a weird name (like Giuseppe Supwitdat) or a play on words or a real thing (like Chuck Stake), or even like a prank call name (like Hugh Jazz).
Keep it short and sweet.
Don't drone on and lose sight of the fact that this is short form.
Maybe quirks that make you go "WTF?!" Your job is once the game begins, you need to commit to that quirk as though it's a part of your character portfolio.
Don't judge your presentation, don't worry about if you're doing it right, and don't bail on your idea.
Go full- on!
This game will be over before you know it, so have fun playing this character probably for the first and last time ever!

"And with me tonight, my co-anchor, Mickey Louse" "And now let's go to Sports reporter Nancy Reginald for predictions for the big game!" "And let's find out what the precipitation is like this weekend with Weather's Rudolph Bignose." "That's sports/weather, back to you!" Be ready to GIVE focus to performers when it's time, BUT also be ready to take focus too.
If you feel like it's right to move onto the next part of the game, then take focus and redirect it there.
So, whoever the Main Anchor is, keep the game in control, since performers may have big characters that could cause them to lose track of time.
Don't treat the game as weird.

The Main Anchor can show emotion and reactions to the absurdity but treat it more as you have been with these 3 people for years, don't treat it like "This is my first day, and this is WEIRD, right?!?!"
